body.header:
Read this sample answer to the writing task in the previous exercise and find the mistakes. There are 16 and they may be grammatical or lexical errors. Click on them.
Writing Task 1

p.font: The line graph shows the growth in the total global audience for the BBC World Service during 1994 and 2001. The bar chart compares trends in the number of listeners to this service in five regions of the world. It can be seen that, overall, the World Service audience increased at this period. However, in 1999 to 2001, audience growth occurred in only two of the five regions served.

As regards the total global audience, apart from a fall to 5 million on 1998, the number of listeners rose steadily during this period. From 130 million in 1994, it had risen by 153 million before 2001. On average, this is a rise of about 3 million listeners per year. However, the bar chart shows significant changes in the way this total audience was distributed between the different world regions.

The vast majority of listeners had been located in two regions: Africa and the Middle East and Asia and the Pacific. In 1999 and 2001, these audiences grew to 10 million and 5 million listeners for the latter. In contrast, audience sizes in Europe and Eurasia decreased steadily to this period. In 1999, the audience for the latter was 16 million and for the former 12 million. By 2001 these figures had fallen to 2 million and 3 million respectively. The smallest audience of all had been in the Americas, which remained stable at 9 million listeners throughout the period.
In conclusion, over the period described, the BBC World Service broadcast to a growing but less widely dispersed audience.
in - > from: The period referred to began in 1999 and ended in 2001.
to -> of: The figure fell from 143 million to 138 million. This is a drop of 5 million.
by -> to: This is the level it rose to, not the size of the increase.
before -> by: Note the use of past perfect tense for the main verb, 'had risen' in this sentence.
had been -> were: There is no need for the past perfect tense here.
In -> Between: A period that falls between two dates is referred to here.
to -> by: This is the size of the increase referred to here, not the level the figures reached.
to -> over: 'During this period', in other words.
to -> by: This is the size of the decrease, not the level the figures fell to.
